> * you say "generally speaking" *they* (high school students) are toxic, or more toxic than the general population. Do you have any evidence for this? or are you purely drawing evidence from anecdotal evidence?

Generally speaking primary/high school students are misbehaved now days. Their immaturity generally leads to them being quite mean/toxic in the way they act and interact with others. I'm not saying immaturity is the only factor or that it doesn't happen with adults but there are significantly more students who are misbehaved/toxic than adults, when talking percentages.

Some do it due to immaturity, some do it because they think it's cool, some do it because it makes them feel better, some even do it to compensate for something they're unsatisfied with, and there's probably more factors, but the fact remains it's more common with younger individuals. Adults, who are generally more mature, are generally more capable of refraining from acting in such a manner.

So what I am getting from this is you don't know when you are playing with high school/primary but you just **assume** a high % of toxic players you play with are high school/primary students? (Do you have any evidence?)

Once again you bring up some statements regarding toxic/behaviour among high school/primary students compared to adults. If we are talking about full time working adults, people with families I would tend to agree, maybe 25+ of age? But are university students included in "adults"? Are you including 18-24 year olds in the "adult" category? 
Is there a study/evidence that clearly defines each age group and has evidence supporting your claims?



What I am more interested now is what you think the difference in behaviour is between high school/primary students and university students in online games or League specifically.

The thing is about that is, from my experience duruing the hours of about 10 and 2:30 I never get a toxic player. How ever after that until about 2AM should I not have work, I will undoubtedly get toxic players to the point that I try my absolute hardest to never play "After school hours" or during holidays.

Here's the point I am trying to make, the human mind is affected by negativity bias. The negativity bias (also known as the negativity effect) refers to the notion that, even when of equal intensity, things of a more negative nature (e.g. unpleasant thoughts, emotions, or social interactions; harmful/traumatic events) have a greater effect on one's psychological state and processes than do neutral or positive things.

Anecdotal evidence (i.e. whether its your personal experience or mine) is highly inaccurate. Because of the small sample, there is a larger chance that it may be unreliable due to cherry-picked or otherwise non-representative samples of typical cases. Anecdotal evidence is considered dubious support of a generalized claim.

I can guarantee that not every toxic player is a school student (whether high or primary school). The reason people are so quick to assume it is, and blame it on, school students is because the amount of toxic behaviour increases dramatically (almost every game) during school holidays and outside of school hours. So to me, and most other people, it's a pretty safe assumption to make and also seems a little too coincidental.

I think that's the main point I have an issue with.  A few people always talk about it "I always get bad players outside of school hours/ during school holidays" but its all just anecdotal evidence. I have never seen any proof. Maybe you guys don't have the ability to get the information you need to gather proof. I'm personally interested in combating negativity bias, especially during league (Why do I always get the trolls/afks/bads etc out of school hours is so much worse etc). Maybe I will do some digging and research a bit of game data during those times to see what it's **really** like. Are people just remembering negative experiences more than positive? is there a bit of confirmation bias and negativity bias coming into affect here? 

> the amount of toxic behaviour increases dramatically (almost every game) during school holidays and outside of school hours. 

Looking for a source/proof has anyone tried to prove/disprove this? how can you make such a claim without any evidence?

I do see your point. As players we have no way of actually telling how old other people are (you must know that yourself), and the only evidence we can provide is purely circumstantial. I'm just saying that it's too coincidental that no school equals a dramatic increase in toxic behaviour. I'm not saying that all school students are toxic players, or that all toxic players are school students. I'm just saying there's a lot more toxic behaviour when people aren't at school, and I seriously doubt people would wait until holidays, weekends and weekday afternoon/nights to be toxic just so school students get the blame for it.

I'm glad you see my point about not knowing the age. BUT I also mean you are purely using anecdotal evidence to suggest your claims are true. 

> the amount of toxic behaviour increases dramatically (almost every game) during school holidays and outside of school hours.

You are making the above statement purely based on your own or someone you know's experience (anecdotal evidence). Everyone's memory is affected by cognitive bias (e.g. negativity bias and confirmation bias). You would need to do a comparison of 1,000s or 10,000s games in and out of school hours to find out if your statement is true or not.

You're right, I am basing it on my own experience, because I have experienced it. That's why I'm saying something. Same as everyone else is basing on their own experience, because they've experienced it. That's why they're saying something. If you put all of our match history's together you'd have your 1,000's or 10,000's of games in and out of school hours, and most of us seem to think the same thing; no school = more toxic players.
I'd like to point out that the majority of adults work either 9-5 or 6-2:30 jobs, thus making them get on "after school".
Yes, but that doesn't explain the school holidays does it?

To be honest, I wasn't expecting such a huge debate here. I expected two or three comments, however some important thing have been brought up. While we are using anecdotal evidence to say that there is more toxic behaviour outside school hours, there have also been many posts about LoL being toxic every game no matter when it is, so which anecdotal evidence do we accept? Also, there is no concrete evidence stating that these toxic people are all from school. I know adults who don't bother using correct grammar and spelling online as well as teenagers, so I think I can safely say that we can't judge everyone on how they type. Some people just want to put their rage out quickly so they don't take too much time. Also, we get people complaining that it is the school children, so I am sure some people are okay with letting their rage be pinned on others when talked about outside of game.
On one hand I regret making this post as it looks completely serious to some people and it comes across as "I don't want school kids on LoL". However, on the other hand there has been a lot of discussion about this that hasn't resorted to flaming or anything.

I would like it if Riot could look at the statistics of reports and everything in the school holidays for each region and compare them to the periods of time without school holidays though. It would be interesting to know how many more reports and bans happen. However, I'd like to see comparison of percentages, because if more people are playing of course there will be more reports. It'd be cool to see if there is actually a correlation between school holidays and reports/bans that is at a relevant level... or if this is just mostly anecdotal and based off of people thinking "Oh %%%%, school holidays".

I think it would be informative to see some statistics. That said someone (Perhaps a Rioter or community member) could probably come up with a simple survey that people could opt-in to that would compare the 'toxic' behaviours noticed in game between when younger individuals (mostly school students) would usually be on (for arguments sake: 3:30-10:00pm weekdays, 9:00am-10:00pm weekends/holidays) and when those younger individuals wouldn't usually be on. Could even compare that to experiences in real life and/or on social media. I, personally, would be quite interested to see which age group people think have toxicity in numbers and toxicity in degree.

They could also do a survey, make up some purpose for it but one of the questions is age group. Then link that age group to their acc, and check the toxicity level of that acc. Put results in a graph, and I bet the school kids would be the most toxic group. You could also ask for the average hours they play in the survey.

I cant help but feel that the survey you mentioned might be biased. Even though I notice playing during school hours is almost always more fun, with more competent players, more willingness to win, and less "freaking douchebags".

HeartVine is correct. The reason is that kids are mollycoddled by the ways of the current society. But in the same token they are left free to the own **"devices"** (and the pun is intentional). The days of interacting with people outside of the home are dwindling.
For example: How many kids do you know that cannot even tie their own shoelaces at age 8? How many schools hire outside physical education tutoring so that they actually do some physical activity? A lot of them have never even climbed a tree (considered to be against OH&S). How many kids **don't** have a device in their hand on public transport?
And so they act in an antisocial way, and do not know learn social interactions like past generations did. They also certainly cannot handle logic when it is dished up to them, because they are not interested for one reason, and do not know how to theorise for another. Theorising is simply beyond them. They just want that instant gratification, its what the society has taught them. They will make the same mistakes over and over again. And put it down to other people's faults. 
Which brings us to league. I would guess that the majority of players in the game are bronze. Why? Because this is true for most elo(mmr) systems that rate sports. For example in chess 90% of players are in the bottom two tiers (under 1400 elo). And then quite a lot of these are kids because they love playing League in the holidays. So without having true statistics, I think you can just assume it. The other thing is that when you actually talk to them, they use texting shortcuts for actual language, and make many grammatical errors in the process.
**I'm not saying that all kids are like this**, but in my experience the majority are. So now that school holidays are over, rest freer that the player in your game that could not listen to the rest of your team and ended up feeding, griefing or afking is most likely not going to be there.
